Text: For the choirmaster; according to ”The Doe of the Dawn.“ A Psalm of David.
Context: This introductory heading indicates that the Psalm is for the leader of the music and it might be following a tune known as ”The Doe of the Dawn.“ It is attributed to David.

Text: My God, my God, why have You forsaken me? Why are You so far from saving me, so far from the words of my groaning?
Context: This verse expresses a deep sense of abandonment and is a cry to God, feeling distant from salvation and unheard in his suffering.

Text: O my God, I cry by day, but You do not answer, and by night, but I find no rest.
Context: The psalmist continues to describe the persistence of his cries for help and the silence that meets them, emphasizing his continuous suffering.

Text: Yet You are holy, enthroned on the praises of Israel.
Context: In contrast to the previous verses, the psalmist acknowledges God’s holiness and his rightful place receiving Israel‘s worship.

Text: In You our fathers trusted; they trusted and You delivered them.
Context: The psalmist recalls the history of God’s faithfulness to the ancestors of Israel, acknowledging their trust and God‘s deliverance.

Text: To You they cried out and were saved; in You they trusted and were not disappointed.
Context: The psalmist reinforces the motif of trust in God leading to salvation and not to disappointment, adding to the narrative of God’s faithfulness.

Text: But I am a worm and not a man, scorned by mankind and despised by the people.
Context: The psalmist expresses a deep sense of worthlessness and social rejection, comparing himself to a worm.

Text: All who see me mock me; they sneer and shake their heads:
Context: The psalmist describes being mocked and ridiculed by onlookers, likely in the midst of his affliction.

Text: ”He trusts in the LORD; let the LORD deliver him; let Him rescue him, since he delights in Him.“
Context: Those mocking the psalmist quote his trust in the Lord sarcastically, suggesting that if his trust is so great, God should rescue him.

Text: Yet You brought me forth from the womb; You made me secure at my mother‘s breast.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges God’s care and protection from the very beginning of his life.

Text: From birth I was cast upon You; from my mother‘s womb You have been my God.
Context: The psalmist has been depending on God since birth, affirming a lifelong relationship with God.

Text: Be not far from me, for trouble is near and there is no one to help.
Context: The psalmist urgently requests God’s presence, emphasizing his isolation and the immediacy of his need.

Text: Many bulls surround me; strong bulls of Bashan encircle me.
Context: The psalmist uses imagery of powerful and threatening bulls from Bashan to describe the menacing presence of his adversaries.

Text: They open their mouths against me; lions that maul and roar.
Context: The psalmist continues the imagery, likening his enemies to roaring and mauling lions, heightening the sense of danger.

Text: I am poured out like water, and all my bones are disjointed; my heart is like wax; it is melted within me.
Context: The psalmist describes his physical and emotional state as one of total dissolution, with vivid imagery of melting and dislocation.

Text: My strength is dried up like a potsherd, and my tongue clings to the roof of my mouth; You lay me in the dust of death.
Context: He further describes his weakened state with metaphors of dryness and death, suggesting a proximity to the end of life.

Text: Dogs surround me; a band of evildoers encircles me; they have pierced my hands and my feet.
Context: Enemies are depicted as aggressive dogs, and the psalmist describes wounds that are specific and intense.

Text: I can count all my bones; people stare and gloat over me.
Context: The emaciated state of the psalmist is highlighted, with onlookers gazing upon his suffering with a sense of morbid satisfaction.

Text: They divide my garments among them and cast lots for my clothing.
Context: The psalmist feels violated as his enemies gamble for his clothing, adding insult to his injuries.

Text: But You, O LORD, be not far off; O my Strength, come quickly to help me.
Context: Amidst his suffering, the psalmist calls out for God‘s immediate assistance, referring to God as his source of strength.

Text: Deliver my soul from the sword, my precious life from the power of the dog.
Context: The psalmist pleads for rescue from mortal danger, describing his life as precious and in need of salvation.

Text: Rescue me from the mouth of the lions; save me from the horns of the wild oxen.
Context: The plea for deliverance continues, with hope that God will save him from these powerful threats.

Text: I will declare Your name to my brothers; in the assembly I will praise You.
Context: The tone shifts to one of commitment to praise and proclamation among the community, anticipating deliverance.

Text: You who fear the LORD, praise Him! All you descendants of Jacob, honor Him! Revere Him, all you descendants of Israel!
Context: The psalmist invites others who revere God to join in praising and honoring Him, broadening the scope beyond personal deliverance.

Text: For He has not despised or disdained the suffering of the afflicted; He has not hidden His face from him, but has listened to his cry for help.
Context: This verse affirms God’s attentiveness and concern for the afflicted, contradicting the earlier feelings of abandonment.

Text: From You comes my praise in the great assembly; before those who fear You, I will fulfill my vows.
Context: The psalmist expresses gratitude and a vow to praise God publicly for His goodness and faithfulness.

Text: The poor will eat and be satisfied; those who seek the LORD will praise Him. May your hearts live forever!
Context: The verse predicts material and spiritual provision for the needy and a call for everlasting praise from God-seekers.

Text: All the ends of the earth will remember and turn to the LORD, and all the families of the nations will bow down before Him.
Context: The psalmist proclaims a vision of global recognition of and reverence for God, hinting at a universal scope of God‘s lordship.

Text: For dominion belongs to the LORD and He rules over the nations.
Context: God’s ultimate authority and governance over all nations is declared, affirming His supremacy.

Text: All the rich of the earth will feast and worship; all who go down to the dust will kneel before Him—even he who cannot keep his soul alive.
Context: The psalmist envisions universal worship, including both the wealthy and the destitute, recognizing that ultimately all life is dependent on God.

Text: A seed will serve Him; it will be told of the Lord to the next generation.
Context: The legacy of serving and proclaiming God is assured to carry on to subsequent generations.

Text: They will come and declare His righteousness to a people yet unborn—that He has done it.
Context: The final verse captures the forward-looking aspect of God‘s works and righteousness being declared to future peoples, concluding with the confident affirmation that God has acted.
